description: From Middle English empechen, borrowed from Anglo-Norman empecher, from Old French empeechier (“to hinder”), from Latin impedicāre (“to fetter”). Cognate with French empêcher (“to prevent”).

verbs.description: impeach (third-person singular simple present impeaches, present participle impeaching, simple past and past participle impeached)

examples: These ungracious practices of his sons did impeach his journey to the Holy Land.

entries.meaning: To bring a legal proceeding against a public official.
examples: President Clinton was impeached by the House in November 1998, but since the Senate acquitted him, he was not removed from office.

entries.meaning: To charge with impropriety; to discredit; to call into question.
(law) To demonstrate in court that a testimony under oath contradicts another testimony from the same person, usually one taken during deposition.
